articles.headline: World Bank President to Step Down
articles.snippet: Robert B. Zoellick will step down as the head of the World Bank when his five-year term expires on June 30.
articles.abstract: Robert B. Zoellick will step down as the head of the World Bank when his five-year term expires on June 30.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert B. Zoellick will step down as president of the World Bank when his five-year term expires on June 30, the Washington-based institution announced on Wednesday.

articles.headline: A Scrapbook on the Web Catches Fire
articles.snippet: Time to make time for another social network. Pinterest is a free Web pinboard for any photos that you want to share.
articles.abstract: Time to make time for another social network. Pinterest is a free Web pinboard for any photos that you want to share.
articles.lead_paragraph: “OMG! Did you see Brad Pitt’s post on Digglr last night?”

articles.headline: Audit Uncovers Extensive Flaws in Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The findings of San Francisco county officials suggest how pervasive irregularities may be across the nation.
articles.abstract: The findings of San Francisco county officials suggest how pervasive irregularities may be across the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: An audit by San Francisco county officials of about 400 recent foreclosures there determined that almost all involved either legal violations or suspicious documentation, according to a report released Wednesday.

articles.headline: Self-Insured Complicate Health Deal
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s plan to require insurers to cover the costs of birth control is being complicated by the fact that many religiously affiliated organizations insure themselves.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s plan to require insurers to cover the costs of birth control is being complicated by the fact that many religiously affiliated organizations insure themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration thought it had found a way to ease mounting objections to a requirement in the new health care act that all employers — including religiously affiliated hospitals and universities — offer coverage for birth control to women free of charge.

articles.headline: For London Youth, Down and Out Is Way of Life
articles.snippet: The lack of opportunity is feeding a mounting alienation and anger among young people across Europe, threatening to poison the aspirations of a generation.
articles.abstract: The lack of opportunity is feeding a mounting alienation and anger among young people across Europe, threatening to poison the aspirations of a generation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — For almost two years, Nicki Edwards has been looking for work — any type of work.

articles.headline: Interference Seen in Philadelphia Papers
articles.snippet: A proposed sale to a group composed of the region’s most powerful Democrats is pitting newspaper management against the newsroom.
articles.abstract: A proposed sale to a group composed of the region’s most powerful Democrats is pitting newspaper management against the newsroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, Gregory J. Osberg, chief executive and publisher of the Philadelphia Media Network, which publishes The Inquirer, The Daily News and Philly.com, summoned the news organization’s three most senior editors to his office.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and David Carr

articles.headline: Aggressive Acts by Iran Signal Pressure on Its Leadership
articles.snippet: A flurry of actions and statements by Iran this week suggest its leaders are responding frantically, and more unpredictably, to the tightening of sanctions by the West.
articles.abstract: A flurry of actions and statements by Iran this week suggest its leaders are responding frantically, and more unpredictably, to the tightening of sanctions by the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A string of aggressive gestures by Iran this week — assassination attempts on Israelis living abroad that were attributed to Tehran, renewed posturing over its nuclear program and fresh threats of economic retaliation — suggest that Iranian leaders are responding frantically, and with increasing unpredictability, to the tightening of sanctions by the West.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Robert F. Worth
